Question: NoSuchToken exception for StringTokenizer.nextToken(): :When I try to run the code:     import java.io.*;    import java.util.*;    class dothis {      public static void main (String [] args) throws IOException {        BufferedReader f = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("ride.in"));        PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("ride.out")));        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(f.readLine());        String s1 = st.nextToken();            String s2 = st.nextToken();                char[] arr = new char[6];        if (find(s1, arr, 1) == find(s2, arr, 1)) {            out.print("one");        } else {            out.println("two");         }        out.close();                                        }    }With the data file:    ABCDEF    WERTYUit keeps on outputting:    Exception_in_thread_"main"_java.util.NoSuchElementException        at_java.util.StringTokenizer.nextToken(StringTokenizer.java:349)        at_dothis.main(Unknown_Source)I did see a similar question on Stack Overflow, but in that case, the second line of the text file is blank, therefore there wasn't a second token to be read. However, the two first lines of this data file both contain a String. How come a token would not be read for the second line?
Please using this api: PrintWriter.write.

Question: NoSuchToken exception for StringTokenizer.nextToken(): :When I try to run the code:     import java.io.*;    import java.util.*;    class dothis {      public static void main (String [] args) throws IOException {        BufferedReader f = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("ride.in"));        PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("ride.out")));        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(f.readLine());        String s1 = st.nextToken();            String s2 = st.nextToken();                char[] arr = new char[6];        if (find(s1, arr, 1) == find(s2, arr, 1)) {            out.print("one");        } else {            out.println("two");         }        out.close();                                        }    }With the data file:    ABCDEF    WERTYUit keeps on outputting:    Exception_in_thread_"main"_java.util.NoSuchElementException        at_java.util.StringTokenizer.nextToken(StringTokenizer.java:349)        at_dothis.main(Unknown_Source)I did see a similar question on Stack Overflow, but in that case, the second line of the text file is blank, therefore there wasn't a second token to be read. However, the two first lines of this data file both contain a String. How come a token would not be read for the second line?
Please using this api: PrintWriter.write.
Answer: The problem is that you're trying to read two tokens from a line that only contains one token. The StringTokenizer.nextToken() method will throw a NoSuchElementException if there are no more tokens in the StringTokenizer.

In your code, you're trying to read two tokens from the line read by f.readLine(). If the line only contains one token, then there are no more tokens to read, and you'll get a NoSuchElementException.

To fix this, you should check if there are more tokens in the StringTokenizer before trying to read them. Here's how you can modify your code:

```java
import java.io.*;
import java.util.*;

class dothis {
  public static void main (String [] args) throws IOException {
    BufferedReader f = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("ride.in"));
    PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("ride.out")));
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(f.readLine());
    if (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
      String s1 = st.nextToken();
      if (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s2 = st.nextToken();
        char[] arr = new char[6];
        if (find(s1, arr, 1) == find(s2, arr, 1)) {
          out.print("one");
        } else {
          out.println("two");
        }
      }
    }
    out.close();
  }
}
```

In this modified code, the `hasMoreTokens()` method is used to check if there are more tokens in the StringTokenizer before trying to read them. If there are no more tokens, the code will not try to read them, and will not throw a NoSuchElementException.

This should solve your problem.
<<<api>>>: `PrintWriter.write`
<<<code>>>: `out.write("one");` or `out.write("two");`
<<<explanation>>>: `out.write` is used to write a string to the output stream. It does not automatically add a newline character at the end of the string. If you want to write a string followed by a newline, you should use `out.println("one");` or `out.println("two");` instead.
